trans-unit.source: Use SSH keys with Linux-based Hadoop from Linux, Unix, or OS X | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: Use SSH keys with Linux-based Hadoop from Linux, Unix, or OS X | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: You can access Linux-based HDInsight using Secure Shell (SSH). This document provides information on using SSH with HDInsight from Linux, Unix, or OS X clients.
trans-unit.target: You can access Linux-based HDInsight using Secure Shell (SSH). This document provides information on using SSH with HDInsight from Linux, Unix, or OS X clients.

trans-unit.source: Use SSH with Linux-based Hadoop on HDInsight from Linux, Unix, or OS X (preview)
trans-unit.target: Use SSH with Linux-based Hadoop on HDInsight from Linux, Unix, or OS X (preview)

trans-unit.source: Linux-based Azure HDInsight clusters provide the option of using Secure Shell (SSH) access through either a password or an SSH key.
trans-unit.target: Linux-based Azure HDInsight clusters provide the option of using Secure Shell (SSH) access through either a password or an SSH key.

trans-unit.source: This document provides information on using SSH with HDInsight from Linux, Unix, or OS X clients.
trans-unit.target: This document provides information on using SSH with HDInsight from Linux, Unix, or OS X clients.

trans-unit.source: The steps in this article assume you are using a Linux, Unix, or OS X client.
trans-unit.target: The steps in this article assume you are using a Linux, Unix, or OS X client.

trans-unit.source: While these steps may be performed on a Windows-based client if you have installed a package that provides ssh and ssh-keygen (such as Git for Windows,) we recommend that Windows-based clients follow the steps in Use SSH with Linux-based HDInsight (Hadoop) from Windows.
trans-unit.target: While these steps may be performed on a Windows-based client if you have installed a package that provides ssh and ssh-keygen (such as Git for Windows,) we recommend that Windows-based clients follow the steps in Use SSH with Linux-based HDInsight (Hadoop) from Windows.

trans-unit.source: Prerequisites
trans-unit.target: Prerequisites

trans-unit.source: ssh-keygen and ssh for Linux, Unix, and OS X clients.
trans-unit.target: ssh-keygen and ssh for Linux, Unix, and OS X clients.

trans-unit.source: This utilities are usually provided with your operating system, or available through the package management system.
trans-unit.target: This utilities are usually provided with your operating system, or available through the package management system.

trans-unit.source: A modern web browser that supports HTML5.
trans-unit.target: A modern web browser that supports HTML5.

trans-unit.source: OR
trans-unit.target: OR

trans-unit.source: <link><linkText>Azure CLI for Mac, Linux and Windows</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: <link><linkText>Azure CLI for Mac, Linux and Windows</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: What is SSH?
trans-unit.target: What is SSH?

trans-unit.source: SSH is a utility for logging in to, and remotely executing, commands on a remote server.
trans-unit.target: SSH is a utility for logging in to, and remotely executing, commands on a remote server.

trans-unit.source: With Linux-based HDInsight, SSH establishes an encrypted connection to the cluster head node and provides a command line that you use to type in commands.
trans-unit.target: With Linux-based HDInsight, SSH establishes an encrypted connection to the cluster head node and provides a command line that you use to type in commands.

trans-unit.source: Commands are then executed directly on the server.
trans-unit.target: Commands are then executed directly on the server.

trans-unit.source: Create an SSH key (optional)
trans-unit.target: Create an SSH key (optional)

trans-unit.source: When creating a Linux-based HDInsight cluster, you have the option of using a password or an SSH key to authenticate to the server when using SSH.
trans-unit.target: When creating a Linux-based HDInsight cluster, you have the option of using a password or an SSH key to authenticate to the server when using SSH.

trans-unit.source: SSH keys are considered more secure, as they are certificate-based.
trans-unit.target: SSH keys are considered more secure, as they are certificate-based.

trans-unit.source: Use the following information if you plan on using SSH keys with your cluster.
trans-unit.target: Use the following information if you plan on using SSH keys with your cluster.

trans-unit.source: Open a terminal session and use the following command to see if you have any existing SSH keys:
trans-unit.target: Open a terminal session and use the following command to see if you have any existing SSH keys:

trans-unit.source: Look for the following files in the directory listing.
trans-unit.target: Look for the following files in the directory listing.

trans-unit.source: These are common names for public SSH keys.
trans-unit.target: These are common names for public SSH keys.

trans-unit.source: id\_dsa.pub
trans-unit.target: id\_dsa.pub

trans-unit.source: id\_ecdsa.pub
trans-unit.target: id\_ecdsa.pub

trans-unit.source: id\_ed25519.pub
trans-unit.target: id\_ed25519.pub

trans-unit.source: id\_rsa.pub
trans-unit.target: id\_rsa.pub

trans-unit.source: If you do not want to use an existing file, or you have no existing SSH keys, use the following to generate a new file:
trans-unit.target: If you do not want to use an existing file, or you have no existing SSH keys, use the following to generate a new file:

trans-unit.source: You will be prompted for the following information:
trans-unit.target: You will be prompted for the following information:

trans-unit.source: The file location - The location defaults to ~/.ssh/id\_rsa.
trans-unit.target: The file location - The location defaults to ~/.ssh/id\_rsa.

trans-unit.source: A passphrase - You will be prompted to re-enter this.
trans-unit.target: A passphrase - You will be prompted to re-enter this.

trans-unit.source: We strongly recommend that you use a secure passphrase for the key.
trans-unit.target: We strongly recommend that you use a secure passphrase for the key.

trans-unit.source: However, if you forget the passphrase, there is no way to recover it.
trans-unit.target: However, if you forget the passphrase, there is no way to recover it.

trans-unit.source: After the command finishes, you will have two new files, the private key (for example, id\_rsa) and the public key (for example, id\_rsa.pub).
trans-unit.target: After the command finishes, you will have two new files, the private key (for example, id\_rsa) and the public key (for example, id\_rsa.pub).

trans-unit.source: Create a Linux-based HDInsight cluster
trans-unit.target: Create a Linux-based HDInsight cluster

trans-unit.source: When creating a Linux-based HDInsight cluster, you must provide the public key created previously.
trans-unit.target: When creating a Linux-based HDInsight cluster, you must provide the public key created previously.

trans-unit.source: From Linux, Unix, or OS X clients, there are two ways to create an HDInsight cluster:
trans-unit.target: From Linux, Unix, or OS X clients, there are two ways to create an HDInsight cluster:

trans-unit.source: Azure preview portal - Uses a web-based portal to create the cluster.
trans-unit.target: Azure preview portal - Uses a web-based portal to create the cluster.

trans-unit.source: Azure CLI for Mac, Linux and Windows - Uses command-line commands to create the cluster.
trans-unit.target: Azure CLI for Mac, Linux and Windows - Uses command-line commands to create the cluster.

trans-unit.source: Each of these methods will require either a password or a public key.
trans-unit.target: Each of these methods will require either a password or a public key.

trans-unit.source: For complete information on creating a Linux-based HDInsight cluster, see <link><linkText>Provision Linux-based HDInsight clusters</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: For complete information on creating a Linux-based HDInsight cluster, see <link><linkText>Provision Linux-based HDInsight clusters</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: Azure preview portal
trans-unit.target: Azure preview portal

trans-unit.source: When using the Azure preview portal[preview-portal] to create a Linux-based HDInsight cluster, you must enter an SSH USER NAME, and select to enter a PASSWORD or SSH PUBLIC KEY.
trans-unit.target: When using the Azure preview portal[preview-portal] to create a Linux-based HDInsight cluster, you must enter an SSH USER NAME, and select to enter a PASSWORD or SSH PUBLIC KEY.

trans-unit.source: If you select SSH PUBLIC KEY, you can either paste the public key (contained in the file with the .pub extension) into the SSH PublicKey field, or select Select a file to browse and select the public key file.
trans-unit.target: If you select SSH PUBLIC KEY, you can either paste the public key (contained in the file with the .pub extension) into the SSH PublicKey field, or select Select a file to browse and select the public key file.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Image of form asking for public key</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Image of form asking for public key</linkText>

trans-unit.source: The key file is simply a text file.
trans-unit.target: The key file is simply a text file.

trans-unit.source: The contents should appear similar to the following:
trans-unit.target: The contents should appear similar to the following:

trans-unit.source: ssh-rsa  user@system
trans-unit.target: ssh-rsa  user@system

trans-unit.source: This creates a login for the specified user, by using the password or public key you provide.
trans-unit.target: This creates a login for the specified user, by using the password or public key you provide.

trans-unit.source: Azure Command-Line Interface for Mac, Linux and Windows
trans-unit.target: Azure Command-Line Interface for Mac, Linux and Windows

trans-unit.source: You can use the Azure CLI for Mac, Linux and Windows to create a new cluster by using the azure hdinsight cluster create command.
trans-unit.target: You can use the Azure CLI for Mac, Linux and Windows to create a new cluster by using the azure hdinsight cluster create command.

trans-unit.source: For more information on using this command, see <link><linkText>Provision Hadoop Linux clusters in HDInsight using custom options</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: For more information on using this command, see <link><linkText>Provision Hadoop Linux clusters in HDInsight using custom options</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: Connect to a Linux-based HDInsight cluster
trans-unit.target: Connect to a Linux-based HDInsight cluster

trans-unit.source: From a terminal session, use the SSH command to connect to the cluster head node by providing the address and user name:
trans-unit.target: From a terminal session, use the SSH command to connect to the cluster head node by providing the address and user name:

trans-unit.source: SSH address - The cluster name, followed by -ssh.azurehdinsight.net.
trans-unit.target: SSH address - The cluster name, followed by -ssh.azurehdinsight.net.

trans-unit.source: For example, mycluster-ssh.azurehdinsight.net.
trans-unit.target: For example, mycluster-ssh.azurehdinsight.net.

trans-unit.source: User name - The SSH user name you provided when you created the cluster.
trans-unit.target: User name - The SSH user name you provided when you created the cluster.

trans-unit.source: The following example will connect to the cluster mycluster as the user me:
trans-unit.target: The following example will connect to the cluster mycluster as the user me:

trans-unit.source: If you used a password for the user account, you will be prompted to enter the password.
trans-unit.target: If you used a password for the user account, you will be prompted to enter the password.

trans-unit.source: If you used an SSH key that is secured with a passphrase, you will be prompted to enter the passphrase.
trans-unit.target: If you used an SSH key that is secured with a passphrase, you will be prompted to enter the passphrase.

trans-unit.source: Otherwise, SSH will attempt to automatically authenticate by using one of the local private keys on your client.
trans-unit.target: Otherwise, SSH will attempt to automatically authenticate by using one of the local private keys on your client.

trans-unit.source: If SSH does not automatically authenticate with the correct private key, use the -i parameter and specify the path to the private key.
trans-unit.target: If SSH does not automatically authenticate with the correct private key, use the -i parameter and specify the path to the private key.

trans-unit.source: The following example will load the private key from ~/.ssh/id_rsa:
trans-unit.target: The following example will load the private key from ~/.ssh/id_rsa:

trans-unit.source: ssh -i ~/.ssh/id_rsa me@mycluster-ssh.azurehdinsight.net
trans-unit.target: ssh -i ~/.ssh/id_rsa me@mycluster-ssh.azurehdinsight.net

trans-unit.source: If no port is specified, SSH will default to port 22, which will connect to headnode0 on the HDInsight cluster.
trans-unit.target: If no port is specified, SSH will default to port 22, which will connect to headnode0 on the HDInsight cluster.

trans-unit.source: If you use port 23, you will connect to headnode1.
trans-unit.target: If you use port 23, you will connect to headnode1.

trans-unit.source: For more information on the head nodes, see <link><linkText>Availability and reliability of Hadoop clusters in HDInsight</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: For more information on the head nodes, see <link><linkText>Availability and reliability of Hadoop clusters in HDInsight</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: Connect to worker nodes
trans-unit.target: Connect to worker nodes

trans-unit.source: The worker nodes are not directly accessible from outside the Azure datacenter, but they can be accessed from the cluster head node via SSH.
trans-unit.target: The worker nodes are not directly accessible from outside the Azure datacenter, but they can be accessed from the cluster head node via SSH.

trans-unit.source: If you use an SSH key to authenticate your user account, you must complete the following steps on your client:
trans-unit.target: If you use an SSH key to authenticate your user account, you must complete the following steps on your client:

trans-unit.source: Using a text editor, open ~/.ssh/config.
trans-unit.target: Using a text editor, open ~/.ssh/config.

trans-unit.source: If this file doesn't exist, you can create it by entering touch ~/.ssh/config in the terminal.
trans-unit.target: If this file doesn't exist, you can create it by entering touch ~/.ssh/config in the terminal.

trans-unit.source: Add the following to the file.
trans-unit.target: Add the following to the file.

trans-unit.source: Replace CLUSTERNAME with the name of your HDInsight cluster.
trans-unit.target: Replace CLUSTERNAME with the name of your HDInsight cluster.

trans-unit.source: This configures SSH agent forwarding for your HDInsight cluster.
trans-unit.target: This configures SSH agent forwarding for your HDInsight cluster.

trans-unit.source: Test SSH agent forwarding by using the following command from the terminal:
trans-unit.target: Test SSH agent forwarding by using the following command from the terminal:

trans-unit.source: This should return information similar to the following:
trans-unit.target: This should return information similar to the following:

trans-unit.source: If nothing is returned, this indicates that ssh-agent is not running.
trans-unit.target: If nothing is returned, this indicates that ssh-agent is not running.

trans-unit.source: Consult your operating system documentation for specific steps on installing and configuring ssh-agent, or see Using ssh-agent with ssh.
trans-unit.target: Consult your operating system documentation for specific steps on installing and configuring ssh-agent, or see Using ssh-agent with ssh.

trans-unit.source: Once you have verified that ssh-agent is running, use the following to add your SSH private key to the agent:
trans-unit.target: Once you have verified that ssh-agent is running, use the following to add your SSH private key to the agent:

trans-unit.source: If your private key is stored in a different file, replace ~/.ssh/id_rsa with the path to the file.
trans-unit.target: If your private key is stored in a different file, replace ~/.ssh/id_rsa with the path to the file.

trans-unit.source: Use the following steps to connect to the worker nodes for your cluster.
trans-unit.target: Use the following steps to connect to the worker nodes for your cluster.

trans-unit.source: If you use an SSH key to authenticate your account, you must complete the previous steps to verify that agent forwarding is working.
trans-unit.target: If you use an SSH key to authenticate your account, you must complete the previous steps to verify that agent forwarding is working.

trans-unit.source: Connect to the HDInsight cluster by using SSH as described previously.
trans-unit.target: Connect to the HDInsight cluster by using SSH as described previously.

trans-unit.source: Once you are connected, use the following to retrieve a list of the nodes in your cluster.
trans-unit.target: Once you are connected, use the following to retrieve a list of the nodes in your cluster.

trans-unit.source: Replace ADMINPASSWORD with the password for your cluster admin account.
trans-unit.target: Replace ADMINPASSWORD with the password for your cluster admin account.

trans-unit.source: Replace CLUSTERNAME with the name of your cluster.
trans-unit.target: Replace CLUSTERNAME with the name of your cluster.

trans-unit.source: This will return information in JSON format for the nodes in the cluster, including host_name, which contains the fully qualified domain name (FQDN) for each node.
trans-unit.target: This will return information in JSON format for the nodes in the cluster, including host_name, which contains the fully qualified domain name (FQDN) for each node.

trans-unit.source: The following is an example of a host_name entry returned by the curl command:
trans-unit.target: The following is an example of a host_name entry returned by the curl command:

trans-unit.source: Once you have a list of the worker nodes you want to connect to, use the following command from the SSH session to the server to open a connection to a worker node:
trans-unit.target: Once you have a list of the worker nodes you want to connect to, use the following command from the SSH session to the server to open a connection to a worker node:

trans-unit.source: Replace USERNAME with your SSH user name and FQDN with the FQDN for the worker node.
trans-unit.target: Replace USERNAME with your SSH user name and FQDN with the FQDN for the worker node.

trans-unit.source: For example, workernode0.workernode-0-e2f35e63355b4f15a31c460b6d4e1230.j1.internal.cloudapp.net.
trans-unit.target: For example, workernode0.workernode-0-e2f35e63355b4f15a31c460b6d4e1230.j1.internal.cloudapp.net.

trans-unit.source: If you use a password to authentication your SSH session, you will be prompted to enter the password again.
trans-unit.target: If you use a password to authentication your SSH session, you will be prompted to enter the password again.

trans-unit.source: If you use an SSH key, the connection should finish without any prompts.
trans-unit.target: If you use an SSH key, the connection should finish without any prompts.

trans-unit.source: Once the session has been established, the terminal prompt will change from username@headnode to username@workernode to indicate that you are connected to the worker node.
trans-unit.target: Once the session has been established, the terminal prompt will change from username@headnode to username@workernode to indicate that you are connected to the worker node.

trans-unit.source: Any commands you run at this point will run on the worker node.
trans-unit.target: Any commands you run at this point will run on the worker node.

trans-unit.source: Once you have finished performing actions on the worker node, use the exit command to close the session to the worker node.
trans-unit.target: Once you have finished performing actions on the worker node, use the exit command to close the session to the worker node.

trans-unit.source: This will return you to the username@headnode prompt.
trans-unit.target: This will return you to the username@headnode prompt.

trans-unit.source: Add more accounts
trans-unit.target: Add more accounts

trans-unit.source: Generate a new public key and private key for the new user account, as described in the <link><linkText>Create an SSH key</linkText><title></title></link> section.
trans-unit.target: Generate a new public key and private key for the new user account, as described in the <link><linkText>Create an SSH key</linkText><title></title></link> section.

trans-unit.source: The private key should either be generated on a client that the user will use to connect to the cluster, or securely transferred to such a client after creation.
trans-unit.target: The private key should either be generated on a client that the user will use to connect to the cluster, or securely transferred to such a client after creation.

trans-unit.source: From an SSH session to the cluster, add the new user with the following command:
trans-unit.target: From an SSH session to the cluster, add the new user with the following command:

trans-unit.source: This will create a new user account, but will disable password authentication.
trans-unit.target: This will create a new user account, but will disable password authentication.

trans-unit.source: Create the directory and files to hold the key by using the following commands:
trans-unit.target: Create the directory and files to hold the key by using the following commands:

trans-unit.source: When the nano editor opens, copy and paste in the contents of the public key for the new user account.
trans-unit.target: When the nano editor opens, copy and paste in the contents of the public key for the new user account.

trans-unit.source: Finally, use Ctrl-X to save the file and exit the editor.
trans-unit.target: Finally, use Ctrl-X to save the file and exit the editor.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>image of nano editor with example key</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>image of nano editor with example key</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Use the following command to change ownership of the .ssh folder and contents to the new user account:
trans-unit.target: Use the following command to change ownership of the .ssh folder and contents to the new user account:

trans-unit.source: You should now be able to authenticate to the server with the new user account and private key.
trans-unit.target: You should now be able to authenticate to the server with the new user account and private key.

trans-unit.source: <html></html><html></html>SSH tunneling
trans-unit.target: <html></html><html></html>SSH tunneling

trans-unit.source: SSH can be used to tunnel local requests, such as web requests, to the HDInsight cluster.
trans-unit.target: SSH can be used to tunnel local requests, such as web requests, to the HDInsight cluster.

trans-unit.source: The request will then be routed to the requested resource as if it had originated on the HDInsight cluster head node.
trans-unit.target: The request will then be routed to the requested resource as if it had originated on the HDInsight cluster head node.

trans-unit.source: An SSH tunnel is a requirement for accessing the web UI for sopme Hadoop services.
trans-unit.target: An SSH tunnel is a requirement for accessing the web UI for sopme Hadoop services.

trans-unit.source: For example, both the Job History UI or Resource Manager UI can only be accessed using an SSH tunnel.
trans-unit.target: For example, both the Job History UI or Resource Manager UI can only be accessed using an SSH tunnel.

trans-unit.source: Use the following steps to create an SSH tunnel and configure your browser to use it to connect to the cluster.
trans-unit.target: Use the following steps to create an SSH tunnel and configure your browser to use it to connect to the cluster.

trans-unit.source: The following command can be used to create an SSH tunnel to the cluster head node:
trans-unit.target: The following command can be used to create an SSH tunnel to the cluster head node:

trans-unit.source: This creates a connection that routes traffic to local port 9876 to the cluster over SSH.
trans-unit.target: This creates a connection that routes traffic to local port 9876 to the cluster over SSH.

trans-unit.source: The options are:
trans-unit.target: The options are:

trans-unit.source: D 8080 - The local port that will route traffic through the tunnel.
trans-unit.target: D 8080 - The local port that will route traffic through the tunnel.

trans-unit.source: C - Compress all data, because web traffic is mostly text.
trans-unit.target: C - Compress all data, because web traffic is mostly text.

trans-unit.source: 2 - Force SSH to try protocol version 2 only.
trans-unit.target: 2 - Force SSH to try protocol version 2 only.

trans-unit.source: q - Quiet mode.
trans-unit.target: q - Quiet mode.

trans-unit.source: T - Disable pseudo-tty allocation, since we are just forwarding a port.
trans-unit.target: T - Disable pseudo-tty allocation, since we are just forwarding a port.

trans-unit.source: n - Prevent reading of STDIN, since we are just forwarding a port.
trans-unit.target: n - Prevent reading of STDIN, since we are just forwarding a port.

trans-unit.source: N - Do not execute a remote command, since we are just forwarding a port.
trans-unit.target: N - Do not execute a remote command, since we are just forwarding a port.

trans-unit.source: f - Run in the background.
trans-unit.target: f - Run in the background.

trans-unit.source: If you configured the cluster with an SSH key, you may need use the -i parameter and specify the path to the private SSH key.
trans-unit.target: If you configured the cluster with an SSH key, you may need use the -i parameter and specify the path to the private SSH key.

trans-unit.source: Once the command finishes, traffic sent to port 9876 on the local computer will be routed over Secure Sockets Layer (SSL) to the cluster head node and appear to originate there.
trans-unit.target: Once the command finishes, traffic sent to port 9876 on the local computer will be routed over Secure Sockets Layer (SSL) to the cluster head node and appear to originate there.

trans-unit.source: Configure the client program, such as Firefox, to use localhost:9876 as a SOCKS v5 proxy.
trans-unit.target: Configure the client program, such as Firefox, to use localhost:9876 as a SOCKS v5 proxy.

trans-unit.source: Here's what the Firefox settings look like:
trans-unit.target: Here's what the Firefox settings look like:

trans-unit.source: <linkText>image of Firefox settings</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>image of Firefox settings</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Selecting Remote DNS will resolve Domain Name System (DNS) requests by using the HDInsight cluster.
trans-unit.target: Selecting Remote DNS will resolve Domain Name System (DNS) requests by using the HDInsight cluster.

trans-unit.source: If this is unselected, DNS will be resolved locally.
trans-unit.target: If this is unselected, DNS will be resolved locally.

trans-unit.source: You can verify that traffic is being routed through the tunnel by vising a site such as <link><linkText>http://www.whatismyip.com/</linkText><title></title></link> with the proxy settings enabled and disabled in Firefox.
trans-unit.target: You can verify that traffic is being routed through the tunnel by vising a site such as <link><linkText>http://www.whatismyip.com/</linkText><title></title></link> with the proxy settings enabled and disabled in Firefox.

trans-unit.source: While the settings are enabled, the IP address will be for a machine in the Microsoft Azure datacenter.
trans-unit.target: While the settings are enabled, the IP address will be for a machine in the Microsoft Azure datacenter.

trans-unit.source: Browser extensions
trans-unit.target: Browser extensions

trans-unit.source: While configuring the browser to use the tunnel works, you don't usually want to route all traffic over the tunnel.
trans-unit.target: While configuring the browser to use the tunnel works, you don't usually want to route all traffic over the tunnel.

trans-unit.source: Browser extensions such as <link><linkText>FoxyProxy</linkText><title></title></link> support pattern matching for URL requests (FoxyProxy Standard or Plus only), so that only requests for specific URLs will be sent over the tunnel.
trans-unit.target: Browser extensions such as <link><linkText>FoxyProxy</linkText><title></title></link> support pattern matching for URL requests (FoxyProxy Standard or Plus only), so that only requests for specific URLs will be sent over the tunnel.

trans-unit.source: If you have installed FoxyProxy Standard, use the following steps to configure it to only forward traffic for HDInsight over the tunnel:
trans-unit.target: If you have installed FoxyProxy Standard, use the following steps to configure it to only forward traffic for HDInsight over the tunnel:

trans-unit.source: Open the FoxyProxy extension in your browser.
trans-unit.target: Open the FoxyProxy extension in your browser.

trans-unit.source: For example, in Firefox, select the FoxyProxy icon next to the address field.
trans-unit.target: For example, in Firefox, select the FoxyProxy icon next to the address field.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>foxyproxy icon</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>foxyproxy icon</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Select Add New Proxy, select the General tab, and then enter a proxy name of HDInsightProxy.
trans-unit.target: Select Add New Proxy, select the General tab, and then enter a proxy name of HDInsightProxy.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>foxyproxy general</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>foxyproxy general</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Select the Proxy Details tab and populate the following fields:
trans-unit.target: Select the Proxy Details tab and populate the following fields:

trans-unit.source: Host or IP Address - This is localhost, since we are using an SSH tunnel on the local machine.
trans-unit.target: Host or IP Address - This is localhost, since we are using an SSH tunnel on the local machine.

trans-unit.source: Port - This is the port you used for the SSH tunnel.
trans-unit.target: Port - This is the port you used for the SSH tunnel.

trans-unit.source: SOCKS proxy - Select this to enable the browser to use the tunnel as a proxy.
trans-unit.target: SOCKS proxy - Select this to enable the browser to use the tunnel as a proxy.

trans-unit.source: SOCKS v5 - Select this to set the required version for the proxy.
trans-unit.target: SOCKS v5 - Select this to set the required version for the proxy.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>foxyproxy proxy</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>foxyproxy proxy</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Select the URL Patterns tab, and then select Add New Pattern.
trans-unit.target: Select the URL Patterns tab, and then select Add New Pattern.

trans-unit.source: Use the following to define the pattern, and then click OK:
trans-unit.target: Use the following to define the pattern, and then click OK:

trans-unit.source: Pattern Name - headnode - This is just a friendly name for the pattern.
trans-unit.target: Pattern Name - headnode - This is just a friendly name for the pattern.

trans-unit.source: URL pattern - \*headnode\* - This defines a pattern that matches any URL with the word headnode in it.
trans-unit.target: URL pattern - \*headnode\* - This defines a pattern that matches any URL with the word headnode in it.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>foxyproxy pattern</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>foxyproxy pattern</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Click OK to add the proxy and close Proxy Settings.
trans-unit.target: Click OK to add the proxy and close Proxy Settings.

trans-unit.source: At the top of the FoxyProxy dialog, change Select Mode to Use proxies based on their pre-defined patterns and priorities, and then click Close.
trans-unit.target: At the top of the FoxyProxy dialog, change Select Mode to Use proxies based on their pre-defined patterns and priorities, and then click Close.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>foxyproxy select mode</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>foxyproxy select mode</linkText>

trans-unit.source: After following these steps, only requests for URLs that contain the string headnode will be routed over the SSL tunnel.
trans-unit.target: After following these steps, only requests for URLs that contain the string headnode will be routed over the SSL tunnel.

trans-unit.source: Next steps
trans-unit.target: Next steps

trans-unit.source: Now that you understand how to authenticate by using an SSH key, learn how to use MapReduce with Hadoop on HDInsight.
trans-unit.target: Now that you understand how to authenticate by using an SSH key, learn how to use MapReduce with Hadoop on HDInsight.
